para.heading: City Purchasing Agent to establish.
para.text: The City Purchasing Agent shall establish a telephone line or system of telephone lines known as the Vendors' Hot Line.

para.heading: Shared costs.
para.text: Any City agency that uses the hot line to advertise contract opportunities shall contribute its proportional share to the cost of the hot line operation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The primary purpose of the Vendors' Hot Line is to provide callers with prerecorded information on all contracting opportunities that are currently available with agencies or departments of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Information to be provided.
para.text: The Vendors' Hot Line shall provide by prerecorded message to callers the following information:
the title of the bid and other identifying information on the contract;
the nature of the procurement, including whether the procurement is for supplies, services, construction, or commodities;
the amount of deposit required, if any;
a reference to the MBE/WBE requirements;
a reference to the City's policy and requirements regarding recycled and recyclable materials;
the date, time, and place for submission of bids;
a brief description of the type of supplies, services, commodities, or construction being sought and whether the offer is for term contract {sic};
where and when further information on the contract may be obtained; and
any other information the Director of Purchasing considers appropriate and practicable.

para.heading: Initiation.
para.text: The Director of Purchasing shall have the Vendors' Hot Line in operation on or before October 1, 1988.

para.heading: Updates.
para.text: Thereafter, the information on the Vendors' Hot Line shall be updated at least once each week.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 00-005 repealed former Subtitle 40 in its entirety and substituted the following new subtitle, effective April 30, 2000.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: "Board" means the Baltimore City Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Business.
para.text: "Business" means any commercial activity conducted by a person.

para.heading: City.
para.text: "City" means:
the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore; and
any of its agencies, instrumentalities, or units.

para.heading: Contract.
para.text: "Contract" means any agreement in any form.

para.heading: Controlling stockholder.
para.text: "Controlling stockholder" means a stockholder who:
owns more than 25% of the voting stock of a corporation; or
notwithstanding the number of shares that the stockholder owns, has the power to direct or control the direction of the management or policies of a corporation.

para.heading: Convicted.
para.text: "Convicted" includes an accepted plea of nolo contendere.

para.heading: Principal.
para.text: "Principal" means:
a sole proprietor;
a partner, officer, director, or controlling stockholder; or
an employee directly involved in the process of obtaining contracts with public bodies.

para.heading: Public body.
para.text: "Public body" means:
the United States;
the State of Maryland;
the City of Baltimore;
any other local governmental unit in the State, including a county, a municipal corporation, or a bicounty or multicounty governmental entity; and
any agency, instrumentality, or unit of these entities.

section.heading: Probation before judgment.
section.text: For purposes of this subtitle, the Board may treat the imposition of probation before judgment as a conviction.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Notices.
section.text: All notices required to be given under this subtitle must be in writing.

section.heading: Automatic debarment for certain bribery offenses.
section.text: A person is debarred by operation of law from entering into a contract with the City if the person has been convicted under the laws of this State or of the United States for bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe, committed in furtherance of obtaining a contract with a public body.

section.heading: Other bribery offenses.
section.text: The Board may debar a person from entering into a contract with the City, if the person:

para.text: has been convicted under the laws of this State or of the United States for bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe, committed other than in furtherance of obtaining a contract with a public body;
has been convicted under the laws of another state of bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe; or

during the course of an official investigation or other proceeding, has admitted, in writing or under oath, an act or omission that would constitute bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe under the laws of this State, another state, or the United States.

para.heading: Judgments.
para.text: The Board may debar a person from entering into a contract with the City if that person, or a principal of that person, or any other person substantially involved in that person's contracting activities:
has been convicted under the laws of the City, this State, another state, or the United States of:
a criminal offense incident to obtaining, attempting to obtain, or performing a public or private contract; or
fraud, embezzlement, theft, forgery, falsification or destruction of records, or receiving stolen property;
has been convicted of a criminal violation of an antitrust statute of this State, another state, or the United States;

has been convicted of a violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act or of the Mail Fraud Act for acts in connection with the submission of bids or proposals for a public or private contract;
has been convicted of a violation of Title 14 {"Preferences"}, Subtitle 3 {"Minority Business Participation"} of the State Finance and Procurement Article;

has been convicted of conspiracy to commit any act or omission that would constitute grounds for conviction under any of the laws or statutes described in paragraphs (1) through (5) of this subsection;

has been found civilly liable under an antitrust statute of this State, another state, or the United States for acts or omissions in connection with the submission of bids or proposals for a public or private contract; or
has been found in a final administrative determination to have violated the City's Commercial Non-Discrimination Policy, as set forth in Subtitle 29 of this article.

para.heading: Admissions.
para.text: The Board may debar a person from entering into a contract with the City if, during the course of an official investigation or other proceeding, that person, or a principal of that person, or any other person substantially involved in that person's contracting activities has admitted, in writing or under oath, an act or omission that constitutes grounds for conviction or liability under any law described in subsection (a) of this section.

section.heading: Other events.
section.text: The Board may debar a person from entering into a contract with the City:

para.text: if the Board finds that the person was established or operates in a way designed to evade the application of this subtitle or to defeat the purpose of this subtitle;
if the person is a principal, successor, assignee, subsidiary, or affiliate of a person who is debarred or suspended;
for one of the following violations of a contract provision, if the Board believes the violation to be serious enough to justify debarment:
the deliberate failure to perform in accordance with the specifications or within the time limits provided in a contract; or

within the preceding 5 years, the failure to perform or the unsatisfactory performance in accordance with the terms of 1 or more contracts, unless the failure to perform or unsatisfactory performance was caused by acts beyond the control of the person; or
for any other cause that the Board determines to be so serious as to affect the integrity of the procurement process.

section.heading: Designation of representative.
section.text: The City Solicitor may designate one or more Assistant Solicitors to perform the functions and duties assigned by this subtitle.

section.heading: Reports to Board.
section.text: The City Solicitor shall promptly report to the Board any information that indicates a basis for instituting debarment proceedings under this subtitle.

section.heading: Investigations — in general.
section.text: The City Solicitor shall investigate the matters to be determined by the Board in any hearing held under this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies whenever the City Solicitor reasonably believes that a person may have information or may possess or have custody of or control over any potential evidence, wherever situated, that the City Solicitor believes is relevant to an investigation under this subtitle.

para.heading: Service of demand.
para.text: Before making any recommendation to the Board, the City Solicitor may serve on a person described in subsection (a) of this section a written investigative demand that requires the person to do one or more of the following:
be examined under oath;
answer written interrogatories; or
produce documentary material for inspection and copying.

para.heading: Contents of demand.
para.text: The demand of the City Solicitor shall:
state the matter under investigation;
describe the documentary material to be produced with sufficient specificity to indicate fairly the material demanded;
contain a copy of the written interrogatories to be answered;
specify the place for taking testimony and for producing documentary materials; and
prescribe a reasonable time of not less than 3 days after the demand is served within which the person must comply with the demand.

para.heading: Enforcement.
para.text: If the person fails to comply with the demand, the City Solicitor may apply to a court of appropriate jurisdiction for an order requiring compliance.

section.heading: Preliminary recommendations.
section.text: On completing the investigation of a person, the City Solicitor may recommend to the Board whether the Board should:

para.text: institute debarment proceedings against the person; and
suspend the person pending a final decision.

section.heading: Participation in proceedings.
section.text: As a party to any proceeding brought under this subtitle, the City Solicitor may:

para.text: present to the Board the evidence that the City Solicitor considers appropriate; and
recommend to the Board:
whether the Board should debar the person; and
the appropriate time period for the debarment.

para.heading: Units to report to Board.
para.text: Each agency, instrumentality, and unit of the City shall promptly report to the Board any information that indicates a cause for debarment under:
§ 40- 5 {"Automatic debarment for certain bribery offenses"};
§ 40-6 {"Other bribery offenses"};
§ 40-7 {"Violations of other laws"}; or
§ 40-8 {"Other events"}.

para.heading: Board to seek copies of State reports.
para.text: The Board shall seek to obtain from the State Board of Public Works timely copies of reports made to the State Board under § 16-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.heading: Notice and opportunity for hearing — automatic debarments.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies if:
a person is convicted of an offense described in § 40-5 {"Automatic debarment for certain bribery offenses"} of this subtitle; and
that person or a business in which that person is a principal is seeking a contract with the City.

para.heading: Notice of debarment.
para.text: When the Board learns of the conviction, the Board shall:
notify the person of the person's automatic debarment under § 40-5 of this subtitle; and
give the person reasonable opportunity to be heard on whether the stated basis for debarment exists.

section.heading: Notice and opportunity for hearing — other debarments.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies if:
a person is subject to debarment under § 40-6 {"Other bribery offenses"}, § 40-7 {"Violations of other laws"}, or § 40-8 {"Other events"} of this subtitle; and
that person or a business in which that person is a principal is seeking or is performing under a contract with the City.

When the Board receives information that indicates a basis for debarring a person under § 40-6, § 40-7, or § 40-8 of this subtitle, the Board may institute debarment proceedings by notice to that person.
The notice shall state:
the grounds for the debarment;
the person's right to a hearing before the Board; and
that the right to a hearing is waived unless the person files a request for hearing as required by subsection (c) of this section.

para.heading: Request for hearing.
para.text: A request for a hearing must be:
in writing; and
filed with the Board within 30 days after the person received the notice.

para.heading: Debarment on failure to request hearing.
para.text: If the person fails to file a request for hearing as required by subsection (c) of this section, the person:
waives the right to a hearing; and
is debarred.

para.heading: Persons.
para.text: Pending a final decision on a debarment, the Board may suspend any person against whom debarment proceedings have been instituted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Businesses.
para.text: A business is suspended to the same extent that a person is suspended under this section if:
the suspended person's debarment would cause the debarment of the business under § 40-20 {"Debarment of businesses"} of this subtitle; and
the Board notifies the business of its suspension under this subsection.
A person or business suspended under this section may petition the Board to modify or terminate the suspension.
In its sole discretion, the Board may conduct a hearing on the petition.

In considering the petition, the Board shall determine whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the City would be served by continuing, modifying, or terminating the suspension.
The Board shall give the petitioner notice of the Board's decision.
Within 90 days after receipt of a request for a hearing, the Board shall:
conduct a hearing; and
decide whether the person should be debarred.
The time for hearing and decision may be extended by the Board for good cause shown.

para.heading: Factors to be considered.
para.text: In a proceeding under § 40-6, § 40-7, or § 40-8 of this subtitle, the Board shall:
determine whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the City would be served by debarring the person from entering into or performing contracts with the City; and
for that purpose, consider all relevant factors, including:
the nature and seriousness of the act that caused the person to be subject to debarment;
the time the act occurred;
whether and to what extent the person cooperated with authorities investigating the matter;
the conditions under which the person cooperated; and
the conduct of the person since the act occurred.
The Board shall notify the person of the Board's decision.
The notice shall:
state whether the person is debarred for the act in question; and
if the person is debarred, state the period of debarment.

para.heading: Grounds.
para.text: A business is debarred from entering into or performing under a contract with the City if the Board debars any principal in that business.

para.heading: Scope of debarment.
para.text: A business debarred under subsection (a) of this section is debarred to the same extent as the debarred principal.

para.heading: Duration.
para.text: A business remains debarred under this section:
as long as the debarred person remains with the business in any principal capacity; or
until the debarment is removed in accordance with this subtitle.

para.heading: Notice.
para.text: The Board shall notify a business of any debarment of the business under this section.

section.heading: Automatic reinstatement.
section.text: If the conviction that was the basis for a debarment or suspension is reversed or otherwise voided, the debarment or suspension terminates automatically.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A person debarred under this subtitle may petition the Board for removal of the debarment as provided in this section.

para.heading: Bribery offenses.
para.text: For a person debarred under § 40-5 or § 40-6 of this subtitle, the petition may be filed at any time after expiration of 5 years from:
the date of the debarment; or
in the case of an automatic debarment under § 40-5, the date of the Board's notice under § 40-16 {"Notice and opportunity for hearing — automatic debarments"}.

para.heading: Other causes.
para.text: For a person debarred under § 40-7 or § 40-8 of this subtitle, the petition may be filed at any time after expiration of the earlier of:
one-half of the period of debarment; or
5 years from the date of the debarment.
Within 90 days after receipt of a petition, the Board shall:
conduct a hearing; and
decide whether the debarment should be removed.
The time for hearing and decision may be extended by the Board for good cause shown.

para.heading: Factors to be considered.
para.text: In deciding whether the debarment should be removed, the Board shall:
determine whether the integrity of the contracting process and the best interests of the City would be served by continuing the debarment; and
for that purpose, consider all relevant factors, including those listed in § 40-19(b) {"Hearing and decision: Factors to be considered"}.
The Board shall notify the petitioner of the Board's decision.
The notice shall state:
whether the debarment is removed or continued; and
if continued, how long the petitioner must wait before again petitioning for reinstatement.

section.heading: Effect of debarment or suspension.
section.text: A person or business that is debarred or suspended under this subtitle may not, at any time during the period of debarment or suspension, be considered for the award of, be awarded, or perform, directly or indirectly, a contract with the City.

section.heading: Roster of debarred and suspended persons and businesses.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Board shall keep a roster of all persons and businesses debarred or suspended under this subtitle.

para.heading: Public record.
para.text: The roster is a public record.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On submitting a bid, proposal, or other offer or request for a contract with the City, a person must submit an affidavit as provided in this section.

para.heading: Offenses.
para.text: The affidavit shall state whether, to the best of the person's knowledge, the person or any principal in the person's business:
has been convicted of bribery, attempted bribery, or conspiracy to bribe under the laws of this State, any other state, or the United States;
has been convicted of any offense described in § 40-7 of this subtitle;
has been found civilly liable under an antitrust statute as described in § 40-7 of this subtitle; or
is a principal, successor, assignee, subsidiary, or affiliate of a person who is debarred or suspended.

para.heading: Subcontractor and suppliers.
para.text: The affidavit also shall contain the person's affirmation that, in performing the contract with the City, it will not knowingly contract with a person or business debarred or suspended under this subtitle to provide, directly or indirectly, supplies, architectural services, construction or construction-related services, leases of real property, or any other goods or services.

para.heading: Updating prior affidavit.
para.text: The requirements of this section are satisfied if the affidavit:
incorporates by reference the statements contained in an affidavit filed with the City within the previous year; and
states that those statements remain accurate.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, debarment proceedings under this title must be instituted within 5 years after:
the conviction or judgment that constitutes cause for debarment has become final;
the admission that constitutes cause for debarment has been made; or
the occurrence of any other event that constitutes a cause for debarment.

para.heading: Extension of time.
para.text: Debarment proceedings may be brought after the period set forth in subsection (a) of this section if they are instituted within 1 year of when the Board discovered or, by the exercise of ordinary diligence, should have discovered the grounds for debarment.

section.heading: Persons in contempt for unfair labor practices.

para.heading: Board of Estimates to maintain list.

para.text: The Board of Estimates shall establish and maintain a monthly list of all persons found in contempt of court by a federal court of appeals for failure to correct an unfair labor practice prohibited by the National Labor Relations Act (29 U.S.C. § 158, 49 Stat. 452).
This list shall contain the names of those persons found to have engaged in these practices during the 2-year period before the date of the list.

para.heading: Listed persons barred from contracting with City.

para.text: The Board will consider any company whose name appears on this list to have violated this ordinance and shall upon a formal charge and hearing of the facts, inform that company of its inadmission to the procedure for awarding of public works, services, or supply contracts or subcontracts.
Nor shall any contract or subcontract be let to a bidder whose bid includes supplies from the adjudged violator.

para.heading: Exceptions — certain manufacturers.
para.text: This restriction does not prohibit the awarding of a contract to a company whose name does not appear on such a list but whose goods manufactured include component parts manufactured by a company whose name does appear on the list.

para.heading: Exceptions — emergency contract with sole source.
para.text: This restriction does not apply during an emergency situation when the listed person is the sole source of supply for the goods or services.

para.heading: Contracts prohibited.
para.text: No contract shall be awarded to an individual, organization, or corporation which, at the time of the award, owes delinquent taxes to Baltimore City.

para.heading: Affidavit required.
para.text: Beginning 60 days after the effective date of this section, any individual, organization, or corporation bidding or seeking to obtain the award for City contracts shall submit an affidavit attesting that all tax obligations have been met, and that no delinquent taxes are owed to Baltimore City.

para.heading: Penalties for misrepresentation.
para.text: Any individual, or representative of an organization or corporation who misrepresents his or its tax status, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than $1,000 and/or imprisoned not more than 90 days.

para.heading: Contracts prohibited.
para.text: The City of Baltimore may not purchase any tropical hardwood species listed in subsection (b) of this section, nor may any City-sponsored event utilize these products, nor may City public works contractors utilize these products.

para.heading: Tropical species prohibited.
para.text: Tropical hardwood species include, but are not limited to, the following:

para.heading: Certifications.
para.text: After the effective date of this section:
each wood vendor shall note on each invoice for wood products supplied [the] identity of the manufacturer of the products and that the material supplied is not tropical wood; and
each public works general contractor shall certify that no tropical hardwoods are being used by prime or subcontractors in the awarded project.

para.heading: Exemptions.
para.text: The Board of Estimates may exempt an item or type of product from the requirements of this section upon a showing that such item has no acceptable non-tropical wood equivalent or is required in a designated historic building.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: Nothing in this section applies to any contract, agreement, or memorandum of understanding for the access to or use of the Maryland Image Repository System.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings specified.

para.heading: Face surveillance.
para.text: "Face surveillance" means an automated or semi-automated process that assists in identifying or verifying an individual based on the physical characteristics of the individual's face.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Face surveillance system" means any computer software or application that performs face surveillance.

para.heading: Exclusion.
para.text: "Face surveillance system" does not include:
a biometric security system designed to specifically to protect against unauthorized access to a particular location or an electronic device; or
surveillance technology as defined in Article 19, § 18-1(f) {"Definitions: Surveillance technology"}.

para.heading: Purchase prohibited.
para.text: The City of Baltimore may not purchase or otherwise obtain a face surveillance system or face surveillance systems.

para.heading: Contractor use prohibited.
para.text: The City of Baltimore may not contract with another entity or individual, either directly or as a subcontract, for the use of face surveillance in the City.

para.heading: Termination of section.
para.text: This section automatically expires on December 31, 2022, unless the City Council, after causing an appropriate study to be undertaken, conducting public hearings, and hearing testimonial evidence, finds that the prohibitions set forth in this section remain in the public interest, in which case this section may be extended for 5 more years.
The Department of Finance is hereby authorized to sell any tangible personal property belonging to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore which is no longer needed for municipal purposes.
Such sales may be either public or private and shall be made under such regulations as the Board of Estimates shall, from time to time, by resolution, adopt.

para.heading: Proceeds.
para.text: The proceeds derived from all such sales shall be accounted for as other revenue received by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Certification of rates.
para.text: No bill for gas and electricity or steam furnished to the City may be paid by any department in the City unless the Department of General Services has certified the rate as correct.

para.heading: Supervision of meters.
para.text: The Department of General Services has general supervision of the gas, electric, and steam meters in all departments of the City.
On or before January 1 of every year, each City agency shall provide the Department of Finance with an energy consumption report.
This report shall state:
how the agency has complied to date with the criteria and performance measures established by the Commission on Sustainability;
the amount budgeted for energy consumption in the current fiscal year;
the amount budgeted for energy consumption in the next fiscal year; and
a plan to reduce energy consumption in the next fiscal year in accordance with the criteria and performance measures established by the Commission on Sustainability.
The amounts shall be stated in:
the units of energy billed by the sources, such as gallons, kilowatt-hours, or therms;
the energy equivalent per year in the International System of Units (joules per year) or BTU's by each energy source;
the cost of each type of energy; and
the total cost of energy for each agency.

para.heading: Finance report to Council.
para.text: This information shall be transmitted by the Department of Finance to the City Council on or before March 1 of the same year.

section.heading: No Dumping Clause.
section.text: Every contract awarded by the City shall include a provision that:

para.text: the contractor's violation of any provision of City Health Title 7 {"Waste Control"}, Subtitle 6 {"Prohibited Disposal"}, constitutes a breach of the contract; and
the City may determine, in its discretion, whether the violation is a material breach warranting termination of the contract.

section.heading: Marriage license fees for domestic violence shelters.

para.heading: Collection and remittance.
para.text: Pursuant to State Family Law Article § 2-404(d), the Clerk of the Circuit Court shall:
collect an additional fee of $75 for the issuance of a marriage license in Baltimore City, and
transmit the proceeds from this additional fee to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore on a monthly basis.
The proceeds so transmitted shall be segregated in a special fund and available for appropriation for the sole purpose of operating domestic violence shelters which have a 24-hour intake ability.
The Director of Finance shall disburse the monies in the special fund as provided by the appropriation and by any contracts entered into for this purpose.

para.heading: Reports.
para.text: Any such contract shall provide for annual financial and operating reports to be made in writing and, if requested, by an appearance of a representative of the contractor before the Board of Estimates and/or the City Council or a designated subcommittee thereof.

section.heading: Fees for copying, certifying, etc. records.
section.text: The Director of Finance shall charge and receive the following fees:

para.text: for affixing the City Seal to documents and papers — $2 for each impression;
for authenticating copies of records — $1;
for every search, and for every certificate to a copy — 25¢.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is hereby imposed a charge of $30 for each and every check or like written instrument which is not paid in full for any reason, other than any act of fault or neglect on the part of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, by the financial institution upon which it is drawn when on first return indicates "No Funds" or "Account Closed" or when presented a second time for payment or dishonored regardless of reason (hereinafter designated as "worthless instrument") on every person or other legal entity who presents any such worthless instrument to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore or the Director of Finance of Baltimore City, or any of their agents or employees, in payment of any tax, charge, fee, assessment, or impost of any kind levied or imposed under any law, ordinance, rule, or regulation.

para.heading: Additional charge for each bill.
para.text: When the instrument is submitted in payment of more than 1 City bill, then this charge shall be imposed for each bill.

para.heading: Collection; lien on property.
para.text: Such charge(s) shall be collected by the Director of Finance of Baltimore City, and shall be a lien upon the property involved in any particular case and shall be recorded in the Tax Lien Record maintained by the Collection Division in all appropriate cases, in the same manner and to the same extent as the tax, charge, fee, assessment, or impost in connection with which the worthless instrument was presented in payment is collected and is a lien upon property and is recorded in the aforesaid Tax Lien Record.

annotations.annotation: Pursuant to Charter Art. IV, § 5(c), this subtitle was enacted by Ordinance 22-107 without the Mayor’s signature, on January 11, 2022. Section 2 of that Ordinance provides that it takes effect on February 10, 2022 (“the 30th day after the date it is enacted”) and that “[i]t shall remain effective until September 24, 2024; and, immediately after that date with no further action by the Mayor and City Council, this Ordinance will be abrogated and of no further effect”.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section {subtitle}, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of the Department of Finance or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Funds.
para.text: "Funds" means the $641 million Baltimore City has received from the State and Local Fiscal Recovery Fund.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In order for the City Council to oversee the management of the Funds, the Director, in collaboration with leadership from other City agencies, shall provide the City Council with:
monthly reports;
quarterly briefings;
equity reports; and
annual reports.

para.heading: Monthly reports.
para.text: Each monthly report shall:
provide data and metrics regarding how the funds have:
increased the effectiveness of City government services;
broadened the reach of City government services;
made City government services more efficient; or
made City government services more sustainable; and
identify key performance indicators, benchmarks, and targets relating to:
equity, as defined in Article 1, § 39-1 of the Baltimore City Code;
population growth;
labor and employment;
economic growth, especially the growth of minority and women-owned businesses; and
community benefit.

para.heading: Quarterly briefings.
para.text: Each quarterly briefing shall include financial disclosures regarding:
monthly funding allocations;
limitations on the use of the Funds;
operational expenses, including information regarding community outreach and marketing and promotional materials;
the creation of grants;
procurement procedures; and
disbursement procedures.

para.heading: Deadline.
para.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Director shall submit an annual report to the City Council and the Director of the Department of Legislative Reference.

para.heading: Publication.
para.text: The City Council shall publish the annual report online for public review.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The annual report shall include:
an assessment of disbursement and management of the Funds;
disaggregated data of disbursement recipients;
inequities addressed by the Funds;
recommended steps to address and resolve identified inequities; and
updates regarding community engagement.
